Math_Problem: I have 8 unit cubes of different colors, which I want to glue together into a $2 \times 2 \times 2$ cube. How many distinct $2 \times 2 \times 2$ cubes can I make? Rotations of the same cube are not considered distinct, but reflections are. Instead of determining the number of distinct assemblies up to rotational symmetry, simply find $m = \binom{7}{3}$, where $m$ is the number of ways to choose three of the remaining seven cubes for the three positions that share a face with the fixed cube. The number $$m + 316990099009866=\\frac{32016000000000001}{101}$$ is the product of two distinct prime numbers. Compute the smaller of these two primes.

Connecting_Sentence.A595: Instead of determining the number of distinct assemblies up to rotational symmetry, simply find $m = \binom{7}{3}$, where $m$ is the number of ways to choose three of the remaining seven cubes for the three positions that share a face with the fixed cube.

Synthesised_By.A595: I have 8 unit cubes of different colors, which I want to glue together into a $2 \times 2 \times 2$ cube. How many distinct $2 \times 2 \times 2$ cubes can I make? Rotations of the same cube are not considered distinct, but reflections are. Instead of determining the number of distinct assemblies up to rotational symmetry, simply find $e = (m + 316990099009866)$, where $m = \binom{7}{3}$ is the number of ways to choose three of the remaining seven cubes for the three positions that share a face with the fixed cube.

Synthesised_By.A1494: The number $$316990099009901=\frac{32016000000000001}{101}$$ is the product of two distinct prime numbers. Compute the smaller of these two primes.

Original_Problem.A595: I have 8 unit cubes of different colors, which I want to glue together into a $2 \times 2 \times 2$ cube. How many distinct $2 \times 2 \times 2$ cubes can I make? Rotations of the same cube are not considered distinct, but reflections are.

Original_Problem.A1494: The number $$316990099009901=\frac{32016000000000001}{101}$$ is the product of two distinct prime numbers. Compute the smaller of these two primes.

Claims.expr: N = number of distinct 2x2x2 cubes from 8 distinct unit cubes up to rotations (reflections distinct)
rotations of the cube are considered the same
Fix one specific cube (purple) in top-left-front position
Three positions adjacent to purple (sharing faces)
Ways to choose 3 cubes for adjacent positions: binom(7,3)
Rotations fixing purple position: order 3 (0, 120, 240 degrees around corner axis)
These rotations cycle the 3 adjacent positions
For chosen 3 cubes, assignments to 3 positions: 3!
Remaining positions after fixing purple and 3 adjacent: 4
Total with purple fixed, up to stabilizer: binom(7,3) * 2 * 4!
This equals total N, as fixing specific cube in position and quotienting by stabilizer gives orbit count (equivalent to 8! / 24)
smaller of the two distinct prime factors of 316990099009901 = 32016000000000001 / 101
smaller of the two distinct prime factors of (binom(7,3) + 316990099009866) = 32016000000000001 / 101
